Summary: During a demonstration flight, a U.S. Army flyer flown by Orville Wright nose-dived into the ground from a height of approximately 75 feet, killing Lt. Thomas E. Selfridge, 26, who was a passenger. This was the first recorded airplane fatality in history.  One of two propellers separated in flight, tearing loose the wires bracing the rudder and causing the loss of control of the aircraft.  Orville Wright suffered broken ribs, pelvis and a leg.  Selfridge suffered a crushed skull and died a short time later.

The airship flew into a thunderstorm and encountered a severe downdraft crashing 20 miles north of Helgoland Island into the sea. The ship broke in two and the control car immediately sank drowning its occupants.
First U.S. dirigible Akron exploded just offshore at an altitude of 1,000 ft. during a test flight.
Hydrogen gas which was being vented was sucked into the forward engine and ignited causing the airship to explode and burn at 3,000 ft..
The first fatal airplane accident in Canada occurred when American barnstormer, John M. Bryant, California aviator was killed.
Crashed near the Black Sea, cause unknown.
Exploded and burned near Neuwerk Island,  when hydrogen gas, being vented, was ignited by lightning.
Eugene Lefebvre was the first pilot to ever be killed in an air accident, after his controls jambed while flying in an air show.
Crashed into trees while attempting to land after being shot down by British and French aircraft.
Shot down by British aircraft crashing in flames.
Shot down in flames by the British 39th Home Defence Squadron.
Crashed in a storm.
Shot down by British anti-aircraft fire and aircraft and crashed into the North Sea.
Caught fire and crashed.
Crashed into the sea from an altitude of 3,000 ft. after being hit by British aircraft fire.
Struck by lightning and crashed into the Baltic Sea.
Shot down by British aircraft.
Shot down by aircraft.
Shot down by British aircraft.
Shortly after takeoff from Minneapolis-World Chamberlain Field the engine failed. The aircraft lost altitude and crashed  in a field.
Crashed for unknown reasons. Both pilots and the mechanic were killed.
The mail fligh encountered poor weather conditions and crashed into the ocean while on approach to Gibraltar. The bodies of the crew were never recovered.
Shortly after taking off, the aircraft stalled and crashed .
Shortly after taking off on a training flight, the aircraft dove into the ground and exploded in flames.
After taking off the aircraft stalled and crashed.
The aircraft crashed in a field, short of the runway, a few minutes before its scheduled arrival in Cleveland. The weather was poor with fog.

AcType:
De Havilland DH-4
De Havilland DH-4
Summary: Crashed while attempting to land.
Crashed due to structural failure followed by two explosions and a fire. Attributed to faulty design.
Crashed while making an approach to Le Bourget Airport in Paris. Pilot aborted the landing due to another aircraft on the runway.
On approach to Geraldton the plane crashed near the Murchinson River. Considered the first commercial flight in Australila.
Crashed at Le Bourget field.
Crashed from a height of 500 ft. after experiencing control problems cause by malfunctioning controls.
The plane ditched into the ocean about 40 miles East of Florida after a propeller blade broke. Only the pilot survived, being picked up over 2 days later. The flying boat was named Miss Miami.

AcType: de Havilland DH-18 / Farman F-60 Goliath
Summary: A midair collision occurred at 400 ft. in poor visibility approximately 18 miles north of Beauvais, France. The pilots of both planes were using the road as a route marker in bad weather and poor visibility. This was the  first commercial midair collision in aviation history. Two killed on the de Havilland, five on the Faman F-60.
Aboard were all workers taking part in a flight test. All seventeen aboard were Chinese nationals.
Went down into the English Channel while en route.

The passenger/mail plane lost it's engine while taking off and crashed into trees. Actress Fern Andra survived the accident but her director, Georg Bluen did not. The pilot, Lothar von Richthofen, was also killed. He was a World War I ace and brother of Manfred von Richthofen (The Red Baron).
Lost an engine and could not make an emergency landing because of gusty winds. Stalled while making a turn and crashed.
While attempting to make an emergency landing due to engine problems, the aircraft hit telephone lines and crashed.
The plane stalled shortly after takeoff and crashed.
Shortly after taking off the plane crashed into the sea and sank.
Crashed while on a flight from France.

Route: Toulouse - Barcelona - Valencia - Alicante - Malaga - Rabat
Summary: While flying in foggy conditions the pilot reduced altitude and crashed into a hill.
The plane crashed mid-air due to a structural failure of the tail.
Crashed into a mountain during a snowstorm.
Crashed during a mail flight.

Broke-up in mid air after suffering structural failure at 3,000 ft. after a onboard fire weakened the plane's structure losing a wing. Possibly started by a passenger discarding a match after lighting a cigarette.
The pilot lost control of the aircraft  while on approach in poor weather conditions.
Crashed while on approach to Bucharesst.
Crashed during an emergency landing attempt.
Crashed while attempting a forced landing after encountering heavy rain.
Crashed during a training flight.
Crashed while on a flight from Toulon, France to Algiers, Algeria.  The last known radio contact reported the ship nearly out of fuel and battling strong winds.  Struck by lightning.
Crashed into a montain in poor weather conditions.
Stalled after taking off and crashed into a tree.

Shortly after taking off, witnesses observed a puff of white smoke after which the plane nose-dived into the ground. Fuel starvation. Captain Stewart and seven passengers were killed in an attempted forced landing.
Shortly after takeoff, while flying at a low altitude, in poor visibility, the, aircraft hit a lightning rod, stalled and crashed.
Shortly after take off the plane went out of control and crashed in flames.
While attempting to land the seaplane hit a lightning mast and crashed.
Crashed while attempting to land 10 km from the airport

The Shenandoah was flying over Southern Ohio when she abruptly encountered violent atmospheric conditions (thunderstorms). Powerful air currents buffeted her so severely that her crew was unable to maintain control. Rising rapidly above her pressure height, then falling and rising again, her hull structure was overstressed amidships, breaking the airship in two. Shenandoah's external control car and two engine cars fell free, carrying the dirigible's commanding officer and several other men to their deaths. The stern section came down nearby, while several men were able to fly the bow section to ground as a free balloon.
While in a turn in bad weather, the right wing struck trees and the plane crashed. Failure of an aileron in flight.
Crashed in unknown circumstance.
The pilot suffered sunstroke lost control of the plane and crashed.
While the mail plane was flying at a low altitude, the  aircraft hit trees and crashed in a wooded area.
While in a training filight the aircraft stalled and crashed while attempting to land.
The mail plane crashed into the English Channel and was never found.
Crashed while en route into a mountain in adverse weather conditions. The pilot was flying at too low of an altitude.
Crashed into the ground while descending in poor weather.
Weather related.
The plane made a forced landing at Romney Marsh  in heavy fog.  Engine failure. The pilot initally survived but died a day later.
Too much weight caused the landing gear to collapse as the plane took off for Paris on the first trans-Atlantic passenger flight.
After an engine fire, the pilot attempts to make an emergency landing at Penshurst Airfield but crashed..
Weather related.

The plane was on a flight from London to Paris when power was lost to the starboard engine. The aircraft began to lose altitude until it eventually ditched into the sea about 18 miles from the English coast. The plane stayed afloat long enough for the fishing boat Invicta, piloted by Captain Marshall, to rescue all aboard. The plane was named Prince Henry.

While en route and cruising along the shore, the mail plane's engine failed. The crew made an emergency landing on a beach near Cape Bojador. After the landing, crew was attacked by Maures tribesmen and killed while the aircraft was set on fire and destroyed.
The postal plane crashed into a mountain slope in foggy conditions.
The flight crew encountered poor weather conditions and made an emergency landing. The aircraft landed in a field badly damaged and written off.
Unknown.
While attempting to land, the engine failed, the aircraft stalled and crashed.
Crashed after an unsuccessful attempt at fly into strong headwinds. The engine quit and the plane nosedived into the ground.
Crashed following engine failure.
The three engine seaplane stalled and crashed into the sea shortly after taking off.
Crashed after experiencing engine failure and attempting to make a forced landing.
A broken wire led to the partial loss of the the rudder and a crash landing which resulted in the aircraft striking a tree, killing the flight engineer.
The postal plane crashed for unknown reasons.

The sightseeing plane took off and rose to 400 ft. when the engine failed.  The plane stalled and plunged to the ground in an apple orchard. Engine failure. The pilot was not familiar with the type of aircraft.

While flying 1,000 km east of the Canadian coast, the crew sent a mayday message and the aircraft crashed into the ocean two minutes later. The plane was owned by William Randolph Hearst who financed this nonstop transatlantic flight.
From an altitude of 500 ft. the plane went out of control and crashed  due to a broken wing strut.
The plane crashed while attempting to land at Dakar.
Went into a tailspin and crashed into a corn field about 10 km from the airport.
The mail plane crashed shortly after taking off.
Crashed in the gulf of Finland and never found.
The postal plane crashed at night in poor weather.
A fire erupted aboard the mail plane while en route and crashed.
Became lost in dense fog and flew into trees in the Mohawk Valley while proceeding to Buffalo..
Crashed after experiencing mechanical difficulties.
The wing on the mail plane detached from the aircraft and crashed into the sea.
Crashed in unknown circumstances.
After experiencing turbulence the pilot's seat belt broke and ejecting the pilot.
Spatial disorientation after entering a snowstorm.

The air mail plane crashed into a grove of cottonwood trees and burned. Businessman F.H. Craig was killed and pilot Frank Yegar injured. The pilot descended in altitude due to air pockets.The plane then ran into an air pocket that brought the plane down into the grove of trees.
Crashed into the sea while delivering mail in poor weather.
Crashed into a field after getting lost in fog.

Location:
Florianopolis, Brazil
Florianopolis, Brazil
Florianopolis, Brazil
Summary: An in flight fire caused he pilot to lose control and crash in a field after which a fire erupted.
The cargo plane crashed on it’s inaugural flight. The pilot tried to become airborne without sufficient speed.
After taking off and encountering fog, the pilot decided to  to make a precautionary landing in a field but t hit a cow, crashed and burned. Pilot error.
The "Viper" crashed for unknown reasons.
The mail plane flew into tornado like winds and crashed in a field.
The plane became airborne in a stalled condition, hit a shipsmast and crashed into the Waalhaven.
After taking off the engine failed, the plane stalled and crashed.
Crashed into Puget Sound in dense fog 12 miles off Port Townsend.  Considered the first Canadian air disaster.
Struck a mountain in poor weather
Crashed under unknown circumstances
Crashed to the ground shortly after taking off killing two men and two women.
While attempting to make an emergency landing on the Minam river the plane hit a bolder killing the pilot
Diverted off Kerkira in the Ionian Sea, in thunderstoms and high seas and sank.
While attempting to land, the aircraft overran the runway and hit the perimeter fence.
Crashed into the sea. Reasons unknown.

The plane was making the last of a number of sightseeing flights when one of it's three engines failed. The Plane went out of control at an altitude of 200 ft. and crashed into a railroad freight car. Engine failure followed by a stall during an emergency landing attempt.

The aircraft crashed into a high mountain ridge, exploding on impact. Investigators speculated that upon encountering fog and winds in the treacherous mountain pass, the pilot may have turned the airliner around and was heading back to the airport when the crash occurred.
A wing separated in flight and the plane crashed.

operator: Maddux Airlines / Military - U.S.Army Air Force
Summary: A midair collision occurred  with a US Air Force Boeing PW-9D at 2,000 ft.  Five killed on the Tri-motor, one on the Boeing. Army pilot Lieutenant Howard Keefer, while flying above the airliner, was stunting and performed a steep banking turn downward, in an attempt to pass in front of the airliner. Instead, he misjudged the speed of the Maddux aircraft and his diving plane struck the cockpit of the Ford Tri-motor.  He was found criminally negligent.
An engine failed, the plane stalled and crashed.
The plane collided with a submerged object while taking off.
Crashed while taking off. The muddy field prevented the aircraft from gaining altitude. The plane hit telephone wires and crashed.
Took off, lost power and altitude and crashed into a telegraph tower.

The plane was over the English Channel, approximately 3 miles offshore, when an engine failed due to the failure of a connecting rod on a cylinder.. The pilot tried to return to the airport but the plane ditched into the English Channel. The plane was named "City of Ottawa."
Crashed near Indian Mounds park shortly after taking off. Triple engine failure.
The aircraft crashed into lake Constance while attempting to landing. The landing was hard and the plane broke in two.
The mail plane crashed in fog and low visibility and burned.
The just manufactured aircraft was on its way to be delivered to its new owne rwith  four employees of Lockheed,  two pilots and two engineers when it crashed under unknown circumstances.
Hit terrain in low visibility.
